qas.question: What bridged the middle ages to the modern era?
What is regarded as the start of modern philosophy?
What is 17th century philosophy also referred to as?
What does the Age of Rationalism succeed?
What did the beginning of the 18th century mark the beginning of in Europe?

context: Traditionally, the <a0_0>European intellectual transformation<a0_0/> of and after the Renaissance bridged the Middle Ages and the Modern era. <a1_0>The Age of Reason<a1_0/> in the Western world is generally regarded as being the start of modern philosophy, and a departure from the medieval approach, especially Scholasticism. Early 17th-century philosophy is often called <a2_0>the Age of Rationalism<a2_0/> and is considered to succeed <a3_0>Renaissance philosophy<a3_0/> and precede the Age of Enlightenment, but some consider it as the earliest part of the Enlightenment era in philosophy, extending that era to two centuries. The 18th century saw the beginning of <a4_0>secularization<a4_0/> in Europe, rising to notability in the wake of the French Revolution.
